elements.content: A new third polymorph of copper(II) decanoate has been found by two methods: from the crystallization of the salt–acid solution and from a specific thermal treatment of the polymorph obtained in n-heptane. The new polymorph, whose crystal structure has been solved for the first time, is the most stable from the thermodynamic point of view. It presents a bilayer structure, but with two different types of paddle-wheels catenae with opposite orientations. This polymorphism as well as the temperature vs composition phase diagram of the system, [(1 – x) C9H21CO2H + (x) (C9H21CO2)2Cu], were solved by differential scanning calorimetry, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction, pair distribution function, and optical microscopy. The singularities of the phase diagram are (a) a Krafft-like process of molecular association of the copper(II) decanoate into the acid solution, at about T = 361.5 K and x = 0.022 (forming salt-acid adducts of 1:1 stoichiometry); (b) a fusion transition as an invariant (T = 379.1 K) of the solid salt in excess from the copper(II) decanoate crystal phase to the discotic liquid crystal, forming homeotropic developable domains (seen for the first time in these systems) of the pure salt into the saturated acid solution. These domains are seen not only in the copper(II) decanoate but also in other members of the series, at high salt concentration in the corresponding acid solution, and allow identification of the hexagonal columnar discotic structure of the mesophase (with the exception of the copper(II) butanoate, where the tetragonal domains with tilted disks, paddle-wheels, were seen in the same salt–acid region).

elements.content: Binary phase diagrams between organic salts and its corresponding acids have been object of study for a long time. Many alkaline alkanoate–alkanoic acid binary systems have been studied since the early McBain’s publication in the 1920s on the palmitic acid–sodium palmitate, and oleic acid–potassium oleate systems. Later, in the third quarter of the past century, the interest in organic salts and their mixtures increased greatly with the valuable reviews published by Gordon, Lind, and Franzosini and Sanesi. It is remarkable that in these systems the two members must have in common the same chain to avoid the formation of more than two components in the system.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Binary phase diagrams between organic salts and its corresponding acids have been object of study for a long time. Many alkaline alkanoate-alkanoic acid binary systems have been studied since the early McBain's publication in the 1920s on the palmitic acid-sodium palmitate, and oleic acid-potassium oleate systems. Later, in the third quarter of the past century, the interest in organic salts and their mixtures increased greatly with the valuable reviews published by Gordon, Lind, and Franzosini and Sanesi. It is remarkable that in these systems the two members must have in common the same chain to avoid the formation of more than two components in the system.

elements.content: Acid soaps are molecular associations of the alkanoate anion with the carboxylic group of the acid by hydrogen bonding. Depending on the metallic cation size, one or more acid soaps of different stoichiometries (1:1, 1:2, 1:3, 2:3, etc.) can be formed with either congruent or incongruent melting points (peritectic). In alkaline salt–organic acid binary mixtures, the second case is more common due to the big difference of the melting points of the acid and the salt. The K and Tl binary systems form only one 1:1 molecular association.
elements.clean_text:
Most Interesting Features of the Organic Acid-Organic Salt Systems Are the Formation of Acid Soaps and Mesotectic Point

Acid Soaps

Acid soaps are molecular associations of the alkanoate anion with the carboxylic group of the acid by hydrogen bonding. Depending on the metallic cation size, one or more acid soaps of different stoichiometries (1:1, 1:2, 1:3, 2:3, etc.) can be formed with either congruent or incongruent melting points (peritectic). In alkaline salt-organic acid binary mixtures, the second case is more common due to the big difference of the melting points of the acid and the salt. The K and Tl binary systems form only one 1:1 molecular association.

elements.content: To the best of our knowledge, bivalent metallic cation soaps never form molecular associations of acid soaps. Their behavior is similar to that of a polar solvent–surfactant (e.g., water–sodium dodecyl sulfate) instead. In short, a eutectic at a very low salt mole fraction and with a very low melting point depression is present, as well as a Krafft point (at a temperature and critical concentration) showing molecular association with micellar formation, which explains the dramatic increase of the solubility (typically from 10–3 molal (to 30–40% molar, only in a few degrees of temperature increment). At a much higher concentration, lyotropic liquid crystals phases (hexagonal-nematic, planar-smectic, or even cubic phases) are formed.

Their behavior is similar to that of a polar solvent-surfactant (e.g., water-sodium dodecyl sulfate) instead. In short, a eutectic at a very low salt mole fraction and with a very low melting point depression is present, as well as a Krafft point (at a temperature and critical concentration) showing molecular association with micellar formation, which explains the dramatic increase of the solubility (typically from 10-3 molal (to 30-40% molar, only in a few degrees of temperature increment). At a much higher concentration, lyotropic liquid crystals phases (hexagonal-nematic, planar-smectic, or even cubic phases) are formed.

elements.content: At mixtures of high pure salt content, the pure salt mesophase (if present) may transform into a homogeneous lyotropic region of the same structure. Thus, a singular point appears on the formation of this mesophase, called a mesotectic point. This behavior in the phase diagram near the pure salt is rather common not only in systems with bivalent cation but also in those with monovalent cation.
elements.clean_text:
Mesotectic Point

At mixtures of high pure salt content, the pure salt mesophase (if present) may transform into a homogeneous lyotropic region of the same structure. Thus, a singular point appears on the formation of this mesophase, called a mesotectic point. This behavior in the phase diagram near the pure salt is rather common not only in systems with bivalent cation but also in those with monovalent cation.

elements.content: The organic salt–salt binary systems are also of great interest. They may form cocrystals or intermediate salts of different simple stoichiometries (1:1, 1:2, 2:3, ...), homogeneous liquid crystal regions (lyotropic liquid crystal) in a binary system with only one, both, or no mesogenic components. These systems are carefully revised in an outstanding review article on ionic liquid crystals by Binnemans.
elements.clean_text:
Organic Salt-Organic Salt

The organic salt-salt binary systems are also of great interest. They may form cocrystals or intermediate salts of different simple stoichiometries (1:1, 1:2, 2:3, ...), homogeneous liquid crystal regions (lyotropic liquid crystal) in a binary system with only one, both, or no mesogenic components. These systems are carefully revised in an outstanding review article on ionic liquid crystals by Binnemans.

elements.content: Most metal alkanoates (Me(Cn) x from now on, where Me is the metallic cation (+x), and n the total number of C atoms), show a bilayer structure (alternating ionic and lipidic layers) forming two-dimensional (2D) coordination polymers, as shown in some compounds solved by single crystal and powder diffraction. But in the case of the copper(II), rhodium(II), and ruthenium(II) series the ionic layer is substituted by a paddle-wheel layer (see Figure ), forming a one-dimensional (1D) coordination polymer of paddle-wheels catenae, attracted to each other by van der Waals forces. Actually, from the 1D coordination polymer point of view, the copper(II) alkanoates should be described as dicopper(II) tetra-alkanoate ([Cu2(Cn)4], because the molecular unit (or monomer) is the paddle-wheel (Figure ). The known structures of the copper(II) alkanoates series show these 1D catenae in a bilayer arrangement. However, a new polymorphic structure was discovered recently showing, for the first time, a different packing of two by two interdigitated chains among the paddle-wheels catenae.
elements.clean_text:
Case of the Copper(II) Alkanoates Series

Most metal alkanoates (Me(Cn) x  from now on, where Me is the metallic cation (+x), and n the total number of C atoms), show a bilayer structure (alternating ionic and lipidic layers) forming two-dimensional (2D) coordination polymers, as shown in some compounds solved by single crystal and powder diffraction. But in the case of the copper(II), rhodium(II), and ruthenium(II) series the ionic layer is substituted by a paddle-wheel layer (see Figure ), forming a one-dimensional (1D) coordination polymer of paddle-wheels catenae, attracted to each other by van der Waals forces. Actually, from the 1D coordination polymer point of view, the copper(II) alkanoates should be described as dicopper(II) tetra-alkanoate ([Cu2(Cn)4], because the molecular unit (or monomer) is the paddle-wheel (Figure ). The known structures of the copper(II) alkanoates series show these 1D catenae in a bilayer arrangement. However, a new polymorphic structure was discovered recently showing, for the first time, a different packing of two by two interdigitated chains among the paddle-wheels catenae.

elements.content: Copper(II) alkanoates structure: (a) chromophore group showing the square pyramidal coordination of the copper(II) ion, (b) a paddle-wheel unit; (c) the 1D coordination catenae. R represents alkyl chain.
elements.clean_text: 1  Copper(II) alkanoates structure: (a) chromophore group showing the square pyramidal coordination of the copper(II) ion, (b) a paddle-wheel unit; (c) the 1D coordination catenae. R represents alkyl chain.

elements.content: In 1987, Wood et al. studied some long chain copper(II) alkanoates in 15 different solvents, and they found an abrupt increase in the solubility with temperature similar to that of the Krafft point of surfactants in water. They did not measure at low salt concentration where an ordinary solution (OS, hereafter) could be seen. On the other hand, several complete phase diagrams of alkanoic acid–alkanoate systems were solved, finding a micellar-like solubilization process, similar to that of surfactants in polar or nonpolar solvents. Even more, lyotropic liquid crystal regions and an invariant eutectic point a few degrees below the melting temperature of the solvent were also found, with again the same behavior as a surfactant–solvent phase diagram.
elements.clean_text: In 1987, Wood et al. studied some long chain copper(II) alkanoates in 15 different solvents, and they found an abrupt increase in the solubility with temperature similar to that of the Krafft point of surfactants in water. They did not measure at low salt concentration where an ordinary solution (OS, hereafter) could be seen. On the other hand, several complete phase diagrams of alkanoic acid-alkanoate systems were solved, finding a micellar-like solubilization process, similar to that of surfactants in polar or nonpolar solvents. Even more, lyotropic liquid crystal regions and an invariant eutectic point a few degrees below the melting temperature of the solvent were also found, with again the same behavior as a surfactant-solvent phase diagram.

elements.content: The solubility of several even members (with 8–24 carbons) of the cooper(II) alkanoate series in hydrocarbons has been studied. The hydrocarbons produce a swelling effect in the columnar discotic mesophase of the salt and a nematic lyotropic liquid crystal phase finally appears at high salt concentration. This effect was also observed in the rhodium(II) eicosanoate. Moreover, these compounds form adducts with electron pair donors (e.g., water, organic acids, urea, steroids) that are able to coordinate with the two copper(II) ions in the apical position of the paddle-wheels. These adducts are of great interest in fields such as magnetism or pharmacy.

elements.content: The mesogenicity of these compounds is well-known. The structure of the mesophase studied by X-ray diffraction (XRD), is hexagonal columnar discotic (HCDLC, here on), with the exception of the butanoate member, which is tetragonal. The same paddle-wheel units described above for the room temperature crystal are maintained in the columnar discotic liquid crystal (CDLC here on) and form the disks of this mesophase. It was not possible to find good textures by cooling from the isotropic liquid, because they decompose directly from the mesophase, several degrees above their fusion.

The structure of the mesophase studied by X-ray diffraction (XRD), is hexagonal columnar discotic (HCDLC, here on), with the exception of the butanoate member, which is tetragonal. The same paddle-wheel units described above for the room temperature crystal are maintained in the columnar discotic liquid crystal (CDLC here on) and form the disks of this mesophase. It was not possible to find good textures by cooling from the isotropic liquid, because they decompose directly from the mesophase, several degrees above their fusion.

elements.content: Recently, it has been found that these copper(II) alkanoates worked as real nanoreactors producing nanoparticles either of metallic copper or of copper(II) oxide and hydroxide, depending on the experimental conditions (pyrolysis, decomposition in air, or even by attack of the salt with sodium hydroxide). Moreover, other metal alkanoates could behave too as potential nanoreactors in similar conditions.

Moreover, other metal alkanoates could behave too as potential nanoreactors in similar conditions.

elements.content: In this work, the binary phase diagram of decanoic acid + copper(II) decanoate, HC10 + Cu(C10)2 from now on, is studied by differential scanning calorimetry (DSC), Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), XRD, high-energy X-ray total scattering and pair distribution function (PDF) analysis, and polarizing light microscopy. This study allows determination of different fluid regions: (I) one phase of salt-acid ordinary solution; (II) one phase of salt-acid adducts in acid solution; and (III) two phases of salt mesophase and salt–acid adduct solution. The last heterogeneous region allows getting good textures of the discotic mesophase. Moreover, single crystals of the pure copper(II) salts are able to grow by cooling slowly from the fluid regions with high salt content. This behavior can be extrapolated to any member of the series with different chain lengths.

This study allows determination of different fluid regions: (I) one phase of salt-acid ordinary solution; (II) one phase of salt-acid adducts in acid solution; and (III) two phases of salt mesophase and salt-acid adduct solution. The last heterogeneous region allows getting good textures of the discotic mesophase. Moreover, single crystals of the pure copper(II) salts are able to grow by cooling slowly from the fluid regions with high salt content. This behavior can be extrapolated to any member of the series with different chain lengths.

elements.content: Cu(C10)2 was synthesized following the method described elsewhere, consisting of the dropwise addition of decanoic acid (HC10) (>99.5% Fluka “puriss”) to a hot suspension of basic copper(II) carbonate (Fluka purum p.a. > 95%) in excess, in absolute ethanol (Fluka puriss >99.8%) to which some milliliters of deionized water were also added. After 2–4 days, when the evolution of CO2 was not apparent, the hot solution was filtered to remove the excess of carbonate. Then, the solvent was evaporated to reduce its volume to one-half, and the solution was cooled to room temperature. After 2–3 days at room temperature, the first crystallization of the salt was obtained.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Sample Preparation

Pure Compounds

Cu(C10)2 was synthesized following the method described elsewhere, consisting of the dropwise addition of decanoic acid (HC10) (>99.5% Fluka "puriss") to a hot suspension of basic copper(II) carbonate (Fluka purum p.a. > 95%) in excess, in absolute ethanol (Fluka puriss >99.8%) to which some milliliters of deionized water were also added. After 2-4 days, when the evolution of CO2 was not apparent, the hot solution was filtered to remove the excess of carbonate. Then, the solvent was evaporated to reduce its volume to one-half, and the solution was cooled to room temperature. After 2-3 days at room temperature, the first crystallization of the salt was obtained.

elements.content: The copper(II) decanoate was recrystallized at least three times in n-heptane (Sigma, capillary GC, ≥ 99%) and finally dried under a vacuum at about 383 K until it had a constant weight. The final product took the form of a green-blue powder. The same acid described above was used in the preparation of the binary mixtures. The phase obtained using this method is polymorph A. This method was modified recently, carrying out the recrystallization in benzene, and a new monotropic polymorph B was obtained for the first time.
elements.clean_text: The copper(II) decanoate was recrystallized at least three times in n-heptane (Sigma, capillary GC, ≥ 99%) and finally dried under a vacuum at about 383 K until it had a constant weight. The final product took the form of a green-blue powder. The same acid described above was used in the preparation of the binary mixtures. The phase obtained using this method is polymorph A. This method was modified recently, carrying out the recrystallization in benzene, and a new monotropic polymorph B was obtained for the first time.

elements.content: Crystals of Cu(C10)2 suitable for single crystal X-ray studies were obtained by dissolving this salt in HC10 at high temperature (373 K), and high salt concentrations, cooling at a rate of 0.1 K·min–1, using a LINKAM hot stage, model THMS600. The crystals obtained by this method correspond to a new polymorph (polymorph C, from now on).
elements.clean_text: Crystals of Cu(C10)2 suitable for single crystal X-ray studies were obtained by dissolving this salt in HC10 at high temperature (373 K), and high salt concentrations, cooling at a rate of 0.1 K⋅min-1, using a LINKAM hot stage, model THMS600. The crystals obtained by this method correspond to a new polymorph (polymorph C, from now on).

elements.content: Twenty-three mixtures (of about 3 g each), covering the whole composition range, were prepared by weighing the proper amounts of both components, dissolved in n-heptane (in which solvent, polymorph A is expected), and vacuum-dried using a rotavapor. These solid mixtures were finely grinded in order to get a homogeneous powder, and then stored in a desiccator. The estimated error in the mole fraction varied between ±0.0001 and ±0.001(about 50% of the mixtures). Therefore, the latter error has been considered for the mole fraction.
elements.clean_text:
Mole Fractions of the Binary System

Twenty-three mixtures (of about 3 g each), covering the whole composition range, were prepared by weighing the proper amounts of both components, dissolved in n-heptane (in which solvent, polymorph A is expected), and vacuum-dried using a rotavapor. These solid mixtures were finely grinded in order to get a homogeneous powder, and then stored in a desiccator. The estimated error in the mole fraction varied between ±0.0001 and ±0.001(about 50% of the mixtures). Therefore, the latter error has been considered for the mole fraction.

elements.content: A TA Instruments modulated DSC, model Q20, connected to a RCS cooling unit, was used in normal mode to register all the thermograms, at a heating rate of 5 K·min–1, in the temperature range from 200 to 600 K. Tightly sealed aluminum volatile pans were used, in dry nitrogen, flowing at 50.0 mL·min–1. A MT5Mettler microbalance was used to weigh the samples, ranging between 3 and 10 mg (with an error of ±0.001 mg). The calorimeter was calibrated for temperature using standard samples of In and Sn, supplied by TA Instruments (purity >99.999% and >99.9%, respectively) and of benzoic acid (purity > 99.97%), supplied by the former NBS (lot 39i), and for enthalpy with the In and Sn standards already described.
elements.clean_text:
Differential Scanning Calorimetry

A TA Instruments modulated DSC, model Q20, connected to a RCS cooling unit, was used in normal mode to register all the thermograms, at a heating rate of 5 K⋅min-1, in the temperature range from 200 to 600 K. Tightly sealed aluminum volatile pans were used, in dry nitrogen, flowing at 50.0 mL⋅min-1. A MT5Mettler microbalance was used to weigh the samples, ranging between 3 and 10 mg (with an error of ±0.001 mg). The calorimeter was calibrated for temperature using standard samples of In and Sn, supplied by TA Instruments (purity >99.999% and >99.9%, respectively) and of benzoic acid (purity > 99.97%), supplied by the former NBS (lot 39i), and for enthalpy with the In and Sn standards already described.

elements.content: Onset temperatures were read in all the experiments, with the exception of the solubilization process, in which the intersection of the indium slope (moved to the maximum of the peak) and the baseline was read. The temperature precision obtained was ±0.1 K.

elements.content: To identify the nature of the phases (solid, liquid crystal, or liquid), a Carl Zeiss-Jena polarizing optical microscope, model Zeiss Jenalab pol-30-G0527, coupled to a digital camera, Nikon Coolpix-5400, and equipped with a LINKAM hot stage, model THMS600, connected to a LINKAM programmable temperature-controller, model TMS94, was used.
elements.clean_text:
Polarizing Light Microscopy

To identify the nature of the phases (solid, liquid crystal, or liquid), a Carl Zeiss-Jena polarizing optical microscope, model Zeiss Jenalab pol-30-G0527, coupled to a digital camera, Nikon Coolpix-5400, and equipped with a LINKAM hot stage, model THMS600, connected to a LINKAM programmable temperature-controller, model TMS94, was used.

elements.content: Infrared spectra of samples in KBr pellets were recorded using a Nicolet Magna 750 FTIR spectrometer at a resolution of 2 cm–1. A commercial variable temperature cell, SPECAC VTL-2, adapted for solid samples, was employed to obtain IR spectra of the heated samples.
elements.clean_text:
FTIR Spectroscopy

Infrared spectra of samples in KBr pellets were recorded using a Nicolet Magna 750 FTIR spectrometer at a resolution of 2 cm-1. A commercial variable temperature cell, SPECAC VTL-2, adapted for solid samples, was employed to obtain IR spectra of the heated samples.

elements.content: Synchrotron radiation SCXRD experiments were performed with a wavelength λ = 0.8000 Å for Cu(C10)2 (polymorph C), at 105 K and at RT, at the 911-3 beamline of Max II (Max IV Laboratory, in Lund, Sweden) using a MAR225 CCD area-detector, making phi scans while collecting the data. The oscillation range (Δ φ) used for each image was one degree. The structure was solved and refined using the SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97 programs. The experimental parameters, crystal sizes, and main crystallographic data for the compound studied are shown in Table .
elements.clean_text:
Single Crystal X-ray Diffraction (SCXRD)

Synchrotron radiation SCXRD experiments were performed with a wavelength λ = 0.8000 Å for Cu(C10)2 (polymorph C), at 105 K and at RT, at the 911-3 beamline of Max II (Max IV Laboratory, in Lund, Sweden) using a MAR225 CCD area-detector, making phi scans while collecting the data. The oscillation range (Δ φ) used for each image was one degree. The structure was solved and refined using the SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97 programs. The experimental parameters, crystal sizes, and main crystallographic data for the compound studied are shown in Table .

XRD measurements as a function of temperature were carried out in reflection mode with a Panalytical X’Pert PRO MPD X-ray diffractometer with vertical goniometer θ/θ and RTMS X’Celerator detector equipped with a high-temperature camera Anton Paar HTK1200 (Cu Kα1 radiation, 1.54056 Å, 45 kV, 40 mA, Ni filter). In-situ XRPD scans were measured in inert atmosphere (N2(g)) from 2θ = 2°–40° at several temperatures in the range from 298 to 393 K during heating and cooling, after programming every temperature change at a rate of 3 K·min–1.
elements.clean_text:
Powder X-ray Diffraction (PXRD)

XRD measurements as a function of temperature were carried out in reflection mode with a Panalytical X'Pert PRO MPD X-ray diffractometer with vertical goniometer θ/θ and RTMS X'Celerator detector equipped with a high-temperature camera Anton Paar HTK1200 (Cu Kα1 radiation, 1.54056 Å, 45 kV, 40 mA, Ni filter). In-situ XRPD scans were measured in inert atmosphere (N2(g)) from 2θ = 2°-40° at several temperatures in the range from 298 to 393 K during heating and cooling, after programming every temperature change at a rate of 3 K⋅min-1.

elements.content: Finely powdered dry samples of pure Cu(C10)2 and HC10 + Cu(C10)2 mixtures were loaded into 1.0 mm diameter kapton capillaries. High-energy X-ray total scattering data acquisition was performed at beamline ID15B, at the ESRF. Scattering data were collected at different temperatures with a Mar133 CCD-detector using the Rapid-Acquisition Pair Distribution Function technique. Samples, an empty capillary, and the background were measured at RT from 0–25.0 Å–1. The X-ray wavelength was refined using a CeO2 standard (λ = 0.1419 Å). Corrections for sample–detector distance, tilt angle of the detector with respect to the direction of the incident radiation and polarization were performed using Fit2D. Total scattering structure factors and PDFs were obtained using the PDFGetX3 software.
elements.clean_text:
High-Energy X-ray Total Scattering and PDF Analysis

Finely powdered dry samples of pure Cu(C10)2 and HC10 + Cu(C10)2 mixtures were loaded into 1.0 mm diameter kapton capillaries. High-energy X-ray total scattering data acquisition was performed at beamline ID15B, at the ESRF. Scattering data were collected at different temperatures with a Mar133 CCD-detector using the Rapid-Acquisition Pair Distribution Function technique. Samples, an empty capillary, and the background were measured at RT from 0-25.0 Å-1. The X-ray wavelength was refined using a CeO2 standard (λ = 0.1419 Å). Corrections for sample-detector distance, tilt angle of the detector with respect to the direction of the incident radiation and polarization were performed using Fit2D. Total scattering structure factors and PDFs were obtained using the PDFGetX3 software.

elements.content: A new polymorph of Cu(C10)2 was solved and refined by SCXRD (see Table and Figures and c). This phase presents paddle-wheel units forming 1D coordination polymers (catenae), which are arranged in a bilayer structure. However, two different opposite orientations of the 1D polymers are present in this polymorph with a herringbone order of the alkyl chains, which corresponds to the internal-orientational ordering of the all-trans chains (see Figure ).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structural Study of Cu(C10)2: A New Polymorph (C)

A new polymorph of Cu(C10)2 was solved and refined by SCXRD (see Table  and Figures  and c). This phase presents paddle-wheel units forming 1D coordination polymers (catenae), which are arranged in a bilayer structure. However, two different opposite orientations of the 1D polymers are present in this polymorph with a herringbone order of the alkyl chains, which corresponds to the internal-orientational ordering of the all-trans chains (see Figure ).

elements.content: Crystal structure of Cu(C10)2, polymorph C, in the ac (a) and ab (b) projections, showing the two types of catenae and their orientation (in blue and red) in (b). The H atoms have been hidden for clarity.

elements.content: Schematic structures of polymorphs A (a), B (b), and C (c) of Cu(C10)2, showing the bilayer (a and c) and interdigitated (b) structure, and the orientation of the catenae (with same colors for the same oriented catenae). The arrows represent the different orientation of the paddle-wheels catenae. The H atoms have been hidden for clarity. Note that in polymorph C, the all-trans CH2 planes of the alkyl chains have two different internal orientations (50% each). In polymorphs A and B, instead, all the alkyl chains have the same internal orientation.

The arrows represent the different orientation of the paddle-wheels catenae. The H atoms have been hidden for clarity. Note that in polymorph C, the all-trans CH2 planes of the alkyl chains have two different internal orientations (50% each). In polymorphs A and B, instead, all the alkyl chains have the same internal orientation.

elements.content: The bilayer structure with all the 1D catenae in the same orientation is common in the previously known structures of copper(II) alkanoates, from Cu(C2)2 to Cu(C10)2, and will be referred as polymorph A. On the other hand, polymorph B of Cu(C10)2 shows the same paddle-wheel arrangement and same oriented catenae as polymorph A but different chain packing: interdigitated (not bilayer). Thus, slight variations define the structural differences between the three polymorphs. The schematic structures of the three polymorphs are shown in Figure , where the unit cells and the different-oriented catenae are noted.

elements.content: The thermal properties of Cu(C10)2 have been only studied by Burrows and Ellis and Petricek, so far. These authors give, erroneously, two solid-to-solid transitions, and a fusion point. Moreover, this member of the copper alkanoate series is omitted in refs and , where all the even members from 6 to 24 carbons (except decanoate) and the odd members 7, 9, 11, and 15, were studied. One reason for this could be the rather complicated behavior of the Cu(C10)2 member, which was studied and described later.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Behavior

Pure Components

The thermal properties of Cu(C10)2 have been only studied by Burrows and Ellis and Petricek, so far. These authors give, erroneously, two solid-to-solid transitions, and a fusion point. Moreover, this member of the copper alkanoate series is omitted in refs  and , where all the even members from 6 to 24 carbons (except decanoate) and the odd members 7, 9, 11, and 15, were studied. One reason for this could be the rather complicated behavior of the Cu(C10)2 member, which was studied and described later.

elements.content: The data obtained by DSC on the sample used in the present work are in fair agreement with those provided previously. The DSC thermograms of Cu(C10)2 are shown in Figure . As it can be observed in a first heating (Figure a) of the sample crystallized in n-heptane (polymorph A), an endothermic-exothermic effect appears, which corresponds to a melting-crystallization process. This shows that polymorph A converts into another polymorph on heating, that later melts to the liquid crystal phase. When crystallizing the compound in benzene, polymorph B is obtained, which melts without this endoexo effect (Figure b) at a lower temperature with a higher enthalpy, showing its nature as a monotropic polymorph, that is, not converting into another polymorph on heating. The second heating of both polymorphs is similar, since the same phase is obtained after cooling down (at a rate larger than 5 K·min–1) from the melt. This phase was identified as a mixture of polymorphs A and B by PXRD (both with low crystallinity), and it shows a more pronounced endoexo effect (Figure c). The observation of this thermogram points to the formation of the third polymorph after the melting (endothermic) and crystallization (exothermic) process. Actually, after holding the temperature at 376.0 K (Figure d) and then cooling, new polymorph C is obtained (Figure e). This polymorph is the most stable from the thermodynamic point of view because it presents a slightly higher melting temperature. Polymorph C is also obtained when cooling down from the melt at very low rates (less than 1 K·min–1).

elements.content: The endoexo effect observed on heating (Figure a) can be explained from the crystal structures of polymorphs A and C. In this sense, polymorph A starts to melt into liquid crystal (endothermic part) and, immediately, the paddle-wheel catenae rearrange (exothermic part) crystallizing into the stable polymorph C. On the other hand, the mixture of polymorphs A and B in the second heating (Figure c) melts and crystallizes into polymorph C in two different steps: first polymorph A converts into C and, after that, B does it. It is worth noting that polymorph B only shows crystallization when there are already crystals of polymorph C, which act like seeds in this crystallization effect.

Selected thermograms, previously normalized to “one mole of mixture” for comparison (see , for details), were used to build up the three-dimensional (3D) phase diagram shown in Figure .
elements.clean_text:
Binary Phase Diagram

The HC10 + Cu(C10)2 phase diagram was solved studying more than 50 thermograms (at least two for each one of the 23 mixture, and pure components) obtained by DSC, where all the transition temperatures and enthalpies associated with all the effects were measured. Selected thermograms, previously normalized to "one mole of mixture" for comparison (see , for details), were used to build up the three-dimensional (3D) phase diagram shown in Figure .

elements.content:
The pure acid acts as a solvent and the 1 K decrease is so small because of the low eutectic concentration, typical of the surfactant–solvent phase diagrams.

Surfactant-Like Solubilization Process: A Krafft-Like Point

Above the eutectic point, the salt starts to solubilize (high slope line at the left part of the T vs x plot, in Figure a) forming an OS. Whether or not the salt goes into solution as paddle-wheel molecular units or Cu2+/alkanoate ions could not be elucidated. But, the high slope of this solubilization curve indicates low solubility of the salt until the formation of a Krafft-like point (KP), estimated at T K = 360 K and x = 0.020. The T K isotherm separates the ordinary solution from a region of the phase diagram where a molecular association took place (designed as adduct solution + OS). Above this temperature the solubility of the salt starts to increase very fast, forming the Krafft temperatures line in the phase diagram. Along this line all the DSC thermograms show a round peak corresponding to the solubilization of the salt. This peak moves to higher temperatures and increases in area (enthalpy) with increasing the salt mole fraction reaching a maximum estimated from Figure b at x = 0.561, with a value of ΔH = 19.65 kJ·mol–1, at T = 379.1 K (the pure salt melting point). The molecular association in this region could be due to the adduct formation similar to those described by Kozlevčar et al. The structure of these adducts is shown in Figure .

elements.content: This fusion to the mesophase of the pure salt (yet suspended and in excess in the saturated solution) appears as an invariant above x > 0.56, being an uncommon and unique process. The region of the phase diagram above this invariant temperature has two phases and is anisotropic to the polarizing light, due to the presence of the salt mesophase domains. Consecutive heating and cooling cycles make the preparation apparently isotropic. At this point, the two phases can only be observed by decrossing the polars, proving the existence of homeotropic developable domains, as shown in Figure d. This provides a good method for obtaining liquid crystal textures on compounds that decompose directly from the mesophase before reaching the isotropic melt.

Thus, the column spacing of the columnar discotic phase increases with the acid concentration (see Figure SI.6 of the ).

elements.content: (i) Solid-to-solid (polymorphs A and B to polymorph C) transition line: This transition is observed only in the molar fractions that present the liquid crystal phase (x > 0.56). Since all the mixtures were studied in the second and next heatings, the phase corresponding to free Cu(C10)2 is a mixture of polymorphs A and B, and, therefore, all the DSC thermograms show an endoexo effect. This process (melting–crystallization to polymorph C) increases in temperature with increasing the Cu(C10)2 concentration, and it can be explained due to the kinetic nature of this effect. The polymorph obtained for compositions with x < 0.56 (left part of the phase diagram) is C, so no endoexo effect appears.
elements.clean_text:
Other Events in the Phase Diagram

(i) Solid-to-solid (polymorphs A and B to polymorph C) transition line: This transition is observed only in the molar fractions that present the liquid crystal phase (x > 0.56). Since all the mixtures were studied in the second and next heatings, the phase corresponding to free Cu(C10)2 is a mixture of polymorphs A and B, and, therefore, all the DSC thermograms show an endoexo effect. This process (melting-crystallization to polymorph C) increases in temperature with increasing the Cu(C10)2 concentration, and it can be explained due to the kinetic nature of this effect. The polymorph obtained for compositions with x < 0.56 (left part of the phase diagram) is C, so no endoexo effect appears.

elements.content: (ii) Intermediate zone between the adduct solution and the developable domain regions: in general, the separation of the homogeneous fluid regions (as micellar and lyotropic liquid crystals phases) is not defined by lines, but by regions or intervals of temperature–concentration (e.g., the SDS–water phase diagram). It was not possible to determine exactly the separation region between the adduct solution and the developable domains region, only an estimation can be done around x = 0.56, where the sharp melting point of the free salt starts to appear. In this region, the simple acid salt adducts (of stoichiometry 1:1) may start to add more paddle-wheels in between the two acid ligands (Figure b,c), thus facilitating the homeotropic stacking of paddle-wheel catenae during the formation of the CDLC developable domains.

Identification of the Phases in the Phase Diagram

The identification of the components in every two phase separation and homogeneous region, as well as all the solubilization and invariant processes, was carried out using PDF, FTIR, and PXRD at selected compositions and temperatures (see also ).

elements.content: The characterization of mixture spectra has been done by comparison with those of the pure acid and salt (see ). Infrared spectrum of solid HC10 shows the characteristic broadening of ν (OH) (3500–2200 cm–1) and the carbonyl region (1700 cm–1) corresponding to different H-bonded species present. In the liquid phase above 305 K, some associations are broken and so the intensity of ν(OH) decreases and the carbonyl band shifts to 1713 cm–1. On the other hand, the IR spectrum of Cu(C10)2 shows the characteristic features of all copper(II) alkanoates. The νas(COO–) and the νs(COO–) are measured at 1589 cm–1 at 1412 cm–1 respectively, with a Δ(νas(COO–) – νs(COO–)) = 177 cm–1 as corresponds to a bridging bidentate structure present in these salts. FTIR spectra of the binary system in the carboxylic region at several mole fractions and T > 379.1 K are shown in Figure .

elements.content: High-energy X-ray total scattering experiments of the samples in the crystal and in the fluid phases were carried out. The PDFs provide very clarifying information about the structures and local ordering in the atomic distances in each phase and composition. PDFs for the three pure polymorphs (A, B, and C), at room temperature, and in the CDLC phase, at 393 K are shown in Figure . Peak identification was done using the CIF files with the crystal structure of both samples. Thanks to the solved crystal structures, the different atomic distances can be easily identified. In this figure, it can be observed that the only significant and slight difference is in Cu–Cu distances between adjacent cells (paddle-wheel to paddle-wheel) in accord with the structures of the three polymorphs. The figure also shows that the paddle-wheel structure (1D catenae) still remains in the CDLC phase with minimal changes in its interatomic distances. This fact was seen earlier in a DSC-polarizing optical microscopy-PXRD study on some even members from 12 < nC < 22 and proved by extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) on members with nC = 6, 12, 18, 22, and copper(II) stearate. So, the local structure at short distances is similar for the crystal and for the liquid crystal phases, the difference being the long-range order (above 6–8 Å) lost in the latter, which is obvious for the fluid nature of the mesophase.

elements.content: PDFs were also calculated for two selected mixtures (x = 0.305 and 0.855) and for the pure salt at T > 379.1 K, that is, above the solubilization and melting processes (Figure ). In the three samples the single paddle-wheel structure is observed (distances below 3 Å). The polymeric arrangement (bonding of different paddle-wheels) is observed in both the pure Cu(C10)2 and the 0.855 mixture, as inferred from the distances at 3.2 and 5.2 Å. This is expected for the observed HCDLC phase in the phase diagram. However, in the case of the 0.305 mixture, only the short distances inside a paddle-wheel remain, and the characteristic paddle-wheel to paddle-wheel distances disappear, explaining the existence of isolated paddle-wheels and, therefore, adducts with acid in a (1:1) stoichiometry: Cu2(C10)4·2HC10. This is in agreement with the infrared data.

elements.content: Diffraction experiments were carried out for some of the mixtures and the pure salt as a function of temperature (Figure ). In Figure a, the diffraction patterns of the three polymorphs of Cu(C10)2 (A, B, and C), the hexagonal CDLC phase, and the mixture of phases obtained after cooling from the melt are shown. Although the structures of polymorphs A and C do not differ much (as explained in the SCXRD analysis), showing bilayer structure and 1D catenae arrangement, some slightly different peaks and a higher crystallinity in polymorph C can be detected. The main changes in polymer C with respect to polymer A are the first and second peaks (001 and 002 reflections) appearing at slightly lower angles, corresponding to an increase in the bilayer spacing, and the appearance of three characteristic peaks in the range between 20° and 22°.

elements.content: Different mixtures of phases can be seen at lower temperatures in the samples with composition x = 0.249 (Figure b), 0.509 (Figure c), and 0.806 (Figure d), but the most important feature appears at high temperature: the formation of the CDLC phase in the last one (as in the pure salt), while, in the first two, the pattern of a solution is obtained, showing that there is not long-range order in the fluid phase. Thus, PXRD confirms the formation of copper adducts in solution at concentrations above the OS, up to approximately x = 0.56, and the formation of a heterogeneous region of saturated salt solution and CDLC mesophase of the pure salt (as shown in the T vs. x diagram, Figure a) at higher compositions.

elements.content: It is worth noting that a polymorph C is obtained from the melt as the phase corresponding to free Cu(C10)2 in the compositions with x < 0.56, where HC10 acts as a solvent favoring the crystallization of the most stable polymorph. In fact, single crystals of this phase were obtained this way. On the contrary, a mixture of polymorphs A and B is detected for higher compositions (as it happens for pure Cu(C10)2). Polymorph B is only observed from samples that present a CDLC phase, as it was mentioned before. The reason for this is that the liquid crystal and polymorph B show a similar hexagonal packing of the paddle-wheel catenae (although the former has the alkyl chains melted and the latter ordered), so the partial crystallization of the CDLC phase into polymorph B on cooling is thus explained.

elements.content: In the region 0.523 < x < 1.000 and T > 379.1 K, slow heating and cooling cycles during the sample preparation favor the formation of small developable domains. These domains come from the pure salt mesophase organizing the columns parallel to each other, and perpendicular to the plate and cover of the preparation (homeotropic texture), which is isotropic to the polarizing light. These developable domains with a hexagonal arrangement are only seen if the polars of the polarizing light microscope are decrossed about 20° (see Figure d, for the HC10-Cu(C10)2 system). Later, these domains start to grow forming an intermediate with rotational symmetry, as a result of the bending taking place in the catenae. Finally, the Chandrasekhar texture, typical of all the CDLCs is formed, covering the whole preparation (see Figures and ), due to the connections all of the described domains, that can be observed with crossed polars.

Texture Study of the Columnar Thermotropic Liquid Crystal Developable Domains

In the region 0.523 < x < 1.000 and T > 379.1 K, slow heating and cooling cycles during the sample preparation favor the formation of small developable domains. These domains come from the pure salt mesophase organizing the columns parallel to each other, and perpendicular to the plate and cover of the preparation (homeotropic texture), which is isotropic to the polarizing light. These developable domains with a hexagonal arrangement are only seen if the polars of the polarizing light microscope are decrossed about 20° (see Figure d, for the HC10-Cu(C10)2 system). Later, these domains start to grow forming an intermediate with rotational symmetry, as a result of the bending taking place in the catenae. Finally, the Chandrasekhar texture, typical of all the CDLCs is formed, covering the whole preparation (see Figures  and ), due to the connections all of the described domains, that can be observed with crossed polars.

elements.content: Cu(C4)2 is the only member of the series whose mesophase is tetragonal (see Figure a), and it is also the only one showing tilted disks, as proved by an XRD study on the mesophase. Surprisingly, this fact could be also demonstrated by polarizing light microscopy. In Figure , two pictures of the same tetragonal developable domain of coper(II) butanoate in butyric acid (at 456.8 K, above the salt fusion point), and taken with cross polars rotated 45°, are shown. The tetragonal developable domain’s brightness varies due to the anisotropy of the homeotropic columnar discotic packing. This could be attributed to the disks being tilted with respect to the director vector as proved by XRD (for more details, see ).

A New Method To Obtain Single Crystals

The only structure of an alkanoic acid–copper(II) alkanoate adduct known is the dicopper(II) acetate–diacetic acid one studied by Rao. This adduct is highly hygroscopic and unstable. Other adducts are also known, e.g., the diurea dicopper(II) hexanoate. The presence of salt–acid adducts in acid solution (region above the Krafft temperature line, or the heterogeneous mesophase–adduct acid solution one delimited by the pure salt melting point invariant) have been proved here by different techniques (PXRD, FTIR, PDF). On cooling mixtures of these regions, single crystals start to grow, as the Cu(C5)2 ones shown in Figure , obtained from the pentanoic acid–copper(II) pentanoate system. However, XRD of these crystals show that their structure corresponds to the pure salt, indicating that adducts are not stable in the solid phase.

A New Method To Obtain Single Crystals

The only structure of an alkanoic acid-copper(II) alkanoate adduct known is the dicopper(II) acetate-diacetic acid one studied by Rao. This adduct is highly hygroscopic and unstable. Other adducts are also known, e.g., the diurea dicopper(II) hexanoate. The presence of salt-acid adducts in acid solution (region above the Krafft temperature line, or the heterogeneous mesophase-adduct acid solution one delimited by the pure salt melting point invariant) have been proved here by different techniques (PXRD, FTIR, PDF). On cooling mixtures of these regions, single crystals start to grow, as the Cu(C5)2 ones shown in Figure , obtained from the pentanoic acid-copper(II) pentanoate system. However, XRD of these crystals show that their structure corresponds to the pure salt, indicating that adducts are not stable in the solid phase.

elements.content: According to these facts, a new and effective method to obtain single crystals of the pure salts has been found, which is important because it is difficult to find them by crystallization in conventional solvents. In the case of members of the series with n ≤ 8, only polymorph A is obtained (no other polymorphs were found in these members, so far), while in Cu(C10)2 polymorph C is obtained by this method, as it has been demonstrated in this work.

elements.content: The polymorphism of Cu(C10)2 has been analyzed thoroughly. A new polymorph has been solved, and its structure and thermal behavior has been compared with the others members, explaining also, for the first time, the endoexo effect observed by DSC in this compound. The decanoic acid + copper(II) decanoate binary system has been carefully studied by DSC, and the phases in each region of the temperature–composition diagram were identified by FTIR, PXRD, PDF analysis, and polarizing light microscopy techniques.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The polymorphism of Cu(C10)2 has been analyzed thoroughly. A new polymorph has been solved, and its structure and thermal behavior has been compared with the others members, explaining also, for the first time, the endoexo effect observed by DSC in this compound. The decanoic acid + copper(II) decanoate binary system has been carefully studied by DSC, and the phases in each region of the temperature-composition diagram were identified by FTIR, PXRD, PDF analysis, and polarizing light microscopy techniques.

elements.content: The temperature vs composition (T–x plot) and enthalpy of transition vs composition (Tamann plot) diagrams were thoroughly determined for each region of the binary system. By combining these diagrams, the domains of existence of the various thermally stable phases were brought out. The main features of this phase diagram, that at the same time make evident its importance and interest from the materials study point of view, are

elements.content:
(i) Surfactant-like behavior showing a Krafft-like point and micellar-like solubilization process.

(ii) A unique invariant melting process on the pure salt from the crystal in excess to its CDLC mesophase.

(iii) It was identified the presence of acid–salt adducts only in the homogeneous acid–salt solution.

(iv) CDLC developable domains of the pure salt are formed at x > 0.56 and T > 379.1 K (the melting point invariant of the salt). Taking into account that all the copper(II) alkanoates decompose before reaching the isotropic liquid (the reason that good textures of the mesophase were not possible to obtain), the formation of developable domains makes the phase diagram of great interest. This will help without any doubt in the identification of the CDLC structure (e.g., tetragonal or hexagonal in this case) or even to know whether or not the disks are tilted.

(iv) CDLC developable domains of the pure salt are formed at x > 0.56 and T > 379.1 K (the melting point invariant of the salt). Taking into account that all the copper(II) alkanoates decompose before reaching the isotropic liquid (the reason that good textures of the mesophase were not possible to obtain), the formation of developable domains makes the phase diagram of great interest. This will help without any doubt in the identification of the CDLC structure (e.g., tetragonal or hexagonal in this case) or even to know whether or not the disks are tilted.

elements.content: (v) Single crystals of the copper(II) decanoate are able to grow by cooling slowly from the adduct solution or from the CDLC–adduct solution region. Considering the amphiphilic nature of these organic salts, this point is relevant: after cooling any concentrated solution (in any solvent), precipitation takes place suddenly a few degrees below the Krafft temperatures line. At this point, the concentration of the salts becomes of the order of the critical micellar concentration, and crystals cannot grow. Here, single crystals suitable for SCXRD were obtained by cooling very slowly (at 0.05 K·min–1). This method could be extrapolated to any similar alkanoic acid–copper(II) alkanoate systems or even to other salts with other cations, such as Ru or Rh.

elements.content: Crystallographic information files (cif) of Cu(C10)2-polymorph C solved by SCXRD at 105 and 298 K: CCDC-1022551 and 1022552, respectively. In the Supporting Information file: (1) Normalization of thermograms; (2) DSC thermograms; (3) identification of the phases in each region of the phase diagram; (4) PXRD patterns of the pure components and mixtures at specified temperatures and concentration; (5) the herringbone structure in Polymorph C; (6) FTIR spectra at specified temperatures for the pure components; (7) topology of the Chandrasekhar developable domains; (8) the tilted disk structure of copper(II) butanoate. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

cln_elements.content: Copper(II) alkanoates structure: (a) chromophore group showing the square pyramidal coordination of the copper(II) ion, (b) a paddle-wheel unit; (c) the 1D coordination catenae. R represents alkyl chain.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Copper(II) alkanoates structure: (a) chromophore group showing the square pyramidal coordination of the copper(II) ion, (b) a paddle-wheel unit; (c) the 1D coordination catenae. R represents alkyl chain.

cln_elements.content: Crystal structure of Cu(C10)2, polymorph C, in the ac (a) and ab (b) projections, showing the two types of catenae and their orientation (in blue and red) in (b). The H atoms have been hidden for clarity.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  Crystal structure of Cu(C10)2, polymorph C, in the ac (a) and ab (b) projections, showing the two types of catenae and their orientation (in blue and red) in (b). The H atoms have been hidden for clarity.

cln_elements.content: Schematic structures of polymorphs A (a), B (b), and C (c) of Cu(C10)2, showing the bilayer (a and c) and interdigitated (b) structure, and the orientation of the catenae (with same colors for the same oriented catenae). The arrows represent the different orientation of the paddle-wheels catenae. The H atoms have been hidden for clarity. Note that in polymorph C, the all-trans CH2 planes of the alkyl chains have two different internal orientations (50% each). In polymorphs A and B, instead, all the alkyl chains have the same internal orientation.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  Schematic structures of polymorphs A (a), B (b), and C (c) of Cu(C10)2, showing the bilayer (a and c) and interdigitated (b) structure, and the orientation of the catenae (with same colors for the same oriented catenae). The arrows represent the different orientation of the paddle-wheels catenae. The H atoms have been hidden for clarity. Note that in polymorph C, the all-trans CH2 planes of the alkyl chains have two different internal orientations (50% each). In polymorphs A and B, instead, all the alkyl chains have the same internal orientation.

cln_elements.content: DSC thermograms showing the thermal behavior of Cu(C10)2: (a) polymorph A, (b) polymorph B, (c) second heating of both polymorphs, (d) second or next heating of any polymorph up to 376.0 K and waiting for a few minutes, (e) polymorph C obtained after cooling from 376.0 K. All the thermograms were recorded at 5 K·min–1.
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  DSC thermograms showing the thermal behavior of Cu(C10)2: (a) polymorph A, (b) polymorph B, (c) second heating of both polymorphs, (d) second or next heating of any polymorph up to 376.0 K and waiting for a few minutes, (e) polymorph C obtained after cooling from 376.0 K. All the thermograms were recorded at 5 K⋅min-1.

cln_elements.content: 3D phase diagram of HC10 + Cu(C10)2, showing all the normalized second heating DSC thermograms, for all of the binary mixture studied, including the pure acid and salt.
cln_elements.clean_text: 5  3D phase diagram of HC10 + Cu(C10)2, showing all the normalized second heating DSC thermograms, for all of the binary mixture studied, including the pure acid and salt.

cln_elements.content: (a) Temperature vs. x plot for the HC10 + Cu(C10)2 phase diagram, showing all the two-phase separation regions, and the HC10 + Cu(C10)2 homogeneous solution. Temperatures measured in the second heating thermograms. Krafft-like point estimated values: T K = 360 K, x K(salt) = 0.020. Pyrolysis temperature of the salt = 563.3 K. OS, ordinary solution; KP, Krafft point: x = 0.022; T = 361.5 K. (b) Tamman plot: ΔH vs x in the second heating. Symbols: ●, pure acid; left facing open triangle, pre-eutectic effect; ○, eutectic reaction; □, endoexo effect; △, solubilization of the salt into the acid; and ▲, fusion of the free pure salt to the CDLC.
cln_elements.clean_text: 6  (a) Temperature vs. x plot for the HC10 + Cu(C10)2 phase diagram, showing all the two-phase separation regions, and the HC10 + Cu(C10)2 homogeneous solution. Symbols: ●, pure acid; left facing open triangle, pre-eutectic effect; ○, eutectic reaction; □, endoexo effect; △, solubilization of the salt into the acid; and ▲, fusion of the free pure salt to the CDLC.
